elements.title: Bermuda onion (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the Bermuda onion (pictured) was so closely associated with Bermuda that the island's inhabitants became known as "onions"?

elements.title: Michael Wettlaufer (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that a U.S. Navy plane piloted by Michael Wettlaufer clipped the tower of a Florida TV station while on a training mission, forcing it off the air for nearly five years?

elements.title: Chris Tanasale (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that military officer Chris Tanasale was selected as the mayor of Ambon, Indonesia, to prevent the alienation of local Christians?

elements.title: Me at the zoo (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that YouTube co-founder Jawed Karim has updated the description of his video "Me at the zoo" on multiple occasions to criticize the website's business decisions?

elements.title: Hermannus Reydon (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the Nazis killed more than fifty Dutch nationals in retaliation for the assassinations of Hendrik Seyffardt and Hermannus Reydon by the Dutch resistance?

elements.title: drafted by the Detroit Lions (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that fifteen future Pro Football Hall of Fame players have been drafted by the Detroit Lions?

elements.title: a 2007 pop-punk song by Fall Out Boy (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that a 2007 pop-punk song by Fall Out Boy was named after Michael Jackson's Thriller and begins with a monologue by rapper Jay-Z?

elements.title: shopping cart theory (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the shopping cart is "the ultimate litmus test for whether a person is capable of self-governing", according to the shopping cart theory?

elements.title: a book about book banning (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that a book about book banning was banned?
